verses.text: Then Joshua summoned the Reubenites, the Gadites, and the half-tribe of Manasseh,
verses.comment: Here Joshua gathers the tribes who settled east of the Jordan. Their unique role demonstrates the unity and diversity within the people of God.

verses.text: and said to them, "You have kept all that Moses the servant of the Lord commanded you, and have obeyed my voice in all that I have commanded you.
verses.comment: Joshua affirms their faithfulness both to Moses and to himself, highlighting the importance of apostolic succession and obedience to appointed leadership.

verses.text: You have not abandoned your brothers these many days, to this day, but have kept the charge of the commandment of the Lord your God.
verses.comment: Faithful service and brotherly unity were crucial as Israel conquered the land. This prefigures the unity Christ calls for among His disciples (John 17:20-21).

verses.text: Now that the Lord your God has given rest to your brothers as He promised them, therefore turn and go to your tents, to the land of your possession, which Moses the servant of the Lord gave you beyond the Jordan.
verses.comment: The 'rest' mentioned here is both literal and spiritual, foreshadowing the final and perfect rest in Christ (Heb. 4:8-9).

verses.text: Only be very careful to observe the commandment and the law that Moses the servant of the Lord commanded you: to love the Lord your God, to walk in all His ways, to keep His commandments, to cling to Him, and to serve Him with all your heart and with all your soul."
verses.comment: Joshua repeats the Great Commandment, underlining the importance of love and faithfulness. Obedience flows from love, not mere duty.

verses.text: So Joshua blessed them and sent them away, and they went to their tents.
verses.comment: Joshua, as leader, pronounces a blessing imitating the priestly role. Blessings by leaders carry great spiritual significance, pointing toward the ongoing practice of blessing in sacred assemblies.

verses.text: Now to the half-tribe of Manasseh Moses had given a possession in Bashan, but to the other half Joshua gave a possession among their brothers west of the Jordan. When Joshua sent them away to their tents, he blessed them,
verses.comment: The division of land highlights God's faithfulness to His promises, and the unity among all Israelite tribes despite their geographic separation.

verses.text: and spoke to them, saying, "Return with much wealth to your tents, with very much livestock, with silver, gold, bronze, iron, and with many clothes. Divide the spoil of your enemies with your brothers."
verses.comment: The sharing of spoils displays the principle of charity and just distribution among the people (see Acts 2:44-45).

verses.text: So the sons of Reuben and the sons of Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh returned, and departed from the people of Israel at Shiloh, which is in the land of Canaan, to go to the land of Gilead, the land of their possession, which they had acquired by the command of the Lord through Moses.
verses.comment: Their journey back to their allotted inheritance shows both loyalty and the beginning hints at the geographical tensions among God's people.

verses.text: When they came to the region of the Jordan, which is in the land of Canaan, the sons of Reuben, the sons of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh built there an altar by the Jordan, a great and impressive altar.
verses.comment: The construction of an altar hints at concerns over proper worship, foreshadowing later divisions about worshiping outside the central sanctuary.

verses.text: And the people of Israel heard it said, "Behold, the sons of Reuben and the sons of Gad and the half-tribe of Manasseh have built the altar at the frontier of the land of Canaan, in the region by the Jordan, on the side that pertains to the people of Israel."
verses.comment: News travels quickly and creates suspicion about the intentions of the Eastern tribes. The fear of improper worship is a recurring biblical concern.

verses.text: When the people of Israel heard of it, the whole congregation of the people of Israel gathered at Shiloh to go up against them in war.
verses.comment: Their unity in readying for conflict underlines a concern for purity of worship; see parallels with zeal for the Lord's house (Ps. 69:9; John 2:17).

verses.text: Then the people of Israel sent to the sons of Reuben, the sons of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, in the land of Gilead, Phinehas the son of Eleazar the priest,
verses.comment: Phinehas, as a priestly leader, mediates disputes—prefiguring the sacramental mediation of priests in spiritual matters.

verses.text: and with him ten chiefs, one chief for each of the ancestral tribes of Israel, every one of them was the head of a father’s house among the clans of Israel.
verses.comment: The appointment of elders shows deliberate and ordered Church structure—a principle carried through the ages (see Acts 15:6).

verses.text: And they came to the sons of Reuben, Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh, in the land of Gilead, and they spoke with them, saying,
verses.comment: This meeting sets the stage for restoring unity and guarding the faith against division.

verses.text: "Thus says the whole congregation of the Lord, 'What is this unfaithful act that you have committed against the God of Israel by turning away from following the Lord this day, that you have built yourselves an altar, to rebel this day against the Lord?
verses.comment: The question reveals concern for faithfulness, showing the severity with which Israel guards true worship, a principle seen also throughout Church history.

verses.text: Was not the sin of Peor enough for us, from which we have not cleansed ourselves to this day, although a plague came upon the congregation of the Lord,
verses.comment: Referring to the previous sin at Peor, which resulted in communal punishment, warns against repeating past disobedience. Sin affects the whole community.

verses.text: that you must turn away this day from following the Lord? If you rebel against the Lord today, tomorrow He will be angry with the whole congregation of Israel.
verses.comment: The principle of communal responsibility and consequences for individual sin is highlighted, reflected in the New Testament’s teaching about unity in the Body of Christ (1 Cor. 12:12-27).

verses.text: 'But now, if your land is unclean, cross over into the land of the Lord's possession, where the Lord's tabernacle stands, and take possession among us. But do not rebel against the Lord, nor rebel against us by building yourselves an altar besides the altar of the Lord our God.'
verses.comment: They invite the tribes to rejoin the central place of worship if necessary, emphasizing the unity of worship as essential to faith.

verses.text: Did not Achan the son of Zerah act unfaithfully concerning the devoted things, and wrath fell on all the congregation of Israel? That man did not perish alone in his iniquity!"
verses.comment: Achan’s sin and its consequences are a warning about the effects of individual disobedience on the entire community—teaching the gravity of sin and collective holiness.

verses.text: Then the sons of Reuben, the sons of Gad, and the half-tribe of Manasseh answered and said to the heads of the families of Israel,
verses.comment: The accused tribes respond, signaling an openness to dialogue—a model for harmony and reconciliation within the Church.

verses.text: "The Mighty One, God, the Lord! The Mighty One, God, the Lord! He knows, and let Israel itself know—if it was in rebellion or in unfaithfulness to the Lord, do not spare us this day.
verses.comment: The repetition of God’s name and call for judgment based on truth demonstrates reverence and a willingness to submit to God's justice.

verses.text: If we have built ourselves an altar to turn away from following the Lord, or if to offer burnt offerings or grain offerings or peace offerings on it, may the Lord Himself require it.
verses.comment: Their oath reflects deep accountability, similar to the Church’s self-examination concerning the true faith and worship.

verses.text: But in fact we did it out of fear for a future time, saying, ‘In time to come your children might say to our children, “What have you to do with the Lord, the God of Israel?
verses.comment: Concern for future generations demonstrates the importance of tradition and continuity in faith—vital for the Church’s ongoing life and unity.

verses.text: For the Lord has made the Jordan a boundary between us and you, sons of Reuben and sons of Gad; you have no part in the Lord.’ Thus your children might make our children stop fearing the Lord.’
verses.comment: Physical boundaries can lead to spiritual division. Safeguarding unity remains crucial for God’s people.

verses.text: Therefore we said, ‘Let us now build an altar, not for burnt offering or sacrifice,
verses.comment: The altar is not for sacrifice, maintaining the sole proper place for worship as commanded—paralleling the Church's concept of the true altar.

verses.text: but to be a witness between us and you and between our generations after us, that we might perform the service of the Lord before Him with our burnt offerings, with our sacrifices, and with our peace offerings; so that your children may not say to our children in time to come, ‘You have no portion in the Lord.’"
verses.comment: The altar serves as a perpetual reminder or memorial, showing the importance of sacred signs and memorials for unity in worship and faith.

verses.text: Therefore we said, ‘If in the future they say this to us or to our descendants, we can reply, “See the replica of the altar of the Lord which our fathers made—not for burnt offerings or sacrifices, but to be a witness between us and you.”’
verses.comment: Replicas and memorials play a role in preserving faith across generations, much as Christian liturgy and symbols perpetuate remembrance.

verses.text: Far be it from us to rebel against the Lord, and to turn away this day from following the Lord, by building an altar for burnt offering, grain offering, or sacrifice, apart from the altar of the Lord our God that is before His tabernacle!"
verses.comment: Upholding the central altar prefigures the singularity of true worship, keeping the assembly united in one faith.

verses.text: When Phinehas the priest, the leaders of the congregation, and the heads of the clans of Israel who were with him heard the words spoken by the sons of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh, it pleased them.
verses.comment: Understanding and peace follow honest dialogue, a lesson for resolving divisions in the Church with charity and truth.

verses.text: Phinehas the son of Eleazar the priest said to the sons of Reuben, Gad, and Manasseh, "Today we know that the Lord is in our midst, because you have not acted unfaithfully toward the Lord; now you have delivered the people of Israel from the hand of the Lord."
verses.comment: Reconciliation confirms God's presence among His people, showing how unity and truth draw down divine favor.

verses.text: Then Phinehas the son of Eleazar the priest and the leaders returned from the sons of Reuben and the sons of Gad in the land of Gilead to the land of Canaan, to the people of Israel, and brought back word to them.
verses.comment: Mediation and communication by the priestly leader bring peace and reconciliation to God's assembly—central principles for God's people.

verses.text: The report pleased the people of Israel, and the people of Israel blessed God and spoke no more of going against them in war, to destroy the land where the sons of Reuben and Gad were living.
verses.comment: Peace and unity, as God's people gather in thanksgiving, show the fruitfulness of right worship and reconciliation.

verses.text: The sons of Reuben and the sons of Gad called the altar "Witness," saying, "It is a witness between us that the Lord is God."
verses.comment: The name 'Witness' signifies covenantal faithfulness. Sacred objects can serve as reminders of unity and faith, much as physical signs remind the faithful of God's saving work (e.g. sacraments as visible signs of invisible grace).
